Actinomadura sediminis is a species of actinobacteria that was isolated from a sediment sample collected from a coastal region. It is a Gram-positive, aerobic, and non-spore-forming bacterium. The cells of A. sediminis are typically rod-shaped and exhibit a characteristic branched and mycelial growth pattern, which is a common feature of many actinobacteria.

Taxonomically, A. sediminis belongs to the genus Actinomadura, which is a member of the family Thermomonosporaceae within the order Micromonosporales. The species was first described in 2016 based on its phenotypic, chemotaxonomic, and phylogenetic characteristics.

Actinomadura sediminis is able to grow on a variety of media, including nutrient-rich and minimal media, at temperatures ranging from 20°C to 45°C, with an optimal growth temperature around 30°C. The bacterium is able to degrade various complex organic compounds, suggesting its potential role in the cycling of nutrients in the sedimentary environment from which it was isolated.

Further studies on the physiological, metabolic, and ecological aspects of A. sediminis may provide insights into its adaptations and interactions within the microbial communities of coastal sediments, as well as its potential applications in biotechnology or environmental remediation.
